Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: Canadian culture has changed enormously in recent decades.

It is not always easy to separate changes related to high immigration rates versus changes that would have happened for other reasons.

But one change that has definitely arisen is massive self-censorship in discussions, for fear of being branded a racist, even when the content in question is not racist.

And that is not an imaginary trend. You see it even in government-related leaks, for example when housing and urban development leaders refused to talk about the impact of overseas money on Vancouver house prices for fear of being branded as hateful racists. That is a massive cultural change, keeping silent and self-censoring over obvious truths for fear of being branded falsely as racists.

So yes, high rates of immigration to our cities are absolutely changing our culture. But is that surprising? I mean, what, do you think if a million people from Texas moved to Denmark it would somehow NOT change Denmark's culture?

Comment: Most child labor laws are a joke.  Why, because their are 'exceptions.'  If a child labor law made sense there would be no 'exceptions.'  My 2 daughters and 3 sons were all mowing the yard at 10 years old.  They are now adults and they have all their toes and fingers.  Bosco's has a 14 year old mow his grass and would get his grass in trouble and fined.   I employ over 100 people and years ago quit hiring kids under 18 because of the exact same crap that hit Bosco.   The labor lady went through file after file, timecards, etc for two days looking for a violation.  She found one instance where a kid worked past 9 PM on a Friday.  (she was working with her mother).  We were threatened with a $10,000 fine but it was waived but if it ever happened again, whammo.  An angry parent makes a call because they feel bad for their kid and this happens.  If you worry that much, don't let your kid work.

Comment: I've read the article, and people like Ava went through something horrible.  To be sexually assaulted and then not be able to have recourse to the law because you aren't believed must be agonizing.
However, if I step back from the emotional weight of this particular crime, I can also see the problem that police officers have.
Sexual assault is usually a crime with no other witnesses than the two people involved.  If the victim doesn't come forward soon enough, all physical evidence is usually gone.  The burden of proof is on proving one person's character against another's.  If you add in youth, drinking, and risky behaviour, this becomes even more difficult to untangle.  
Finally, in recent years there's been a huge upsurge in prosecuting sexual assault crimes, especially given how much publicity the issue has received.  Is this article as timely as it would have been, say, 30 years ago? I'm not so sure.

Comment: With respect, that is the perennial task of every mayor in Canada, and most of the premiers.
.
The municipalities are creatures of the provinces.
.
At the time of Confederation, 90% of the population lived on the land.  They did not foresee a time when 85% of people would live in cities, or that we would have an industrial and services based economy, or public health care, or income tax.
.
Accordingly, it is something of an historical accident that the federal government has the lion's share of the revenue raising powers, while the provinces, post 1940, have almost all of the big ticket spending obligations.
.
It is thus virtually unavoidable that the provinces are forever trying to obtain federal funding, and the municipalities are forever trying to obtain provincial (and federal) funding.
.
That's the way ss. 91 and 92 of the BNA were written - against the backdrop of the fiasco of "states'  rights" and the US Civil War.

Comment: Electric cars can easily travel over 1300 kms per day, and drive from Ottawa to Toronto without stopping to charge. We have driven over 120,000 km electrically over the past four years, including three trips to Florida, and countless trips to Ottawa, Montreal, Detroit and other destinations. No range anxiety and never stuck at the side of road with an empty battery.

There is no doubt that electric cars are more than ready for prime time, and the stock market knows it.

Comment: This is nonsense. I fly regularly on both, for a living, and work in the industry and have colleagues at both. Comment: I have been to Hazard, Kentucky. It is not ominous unless you consider Drain, Oregon ominous. The residents are rural Appalachian hill people who need jobs due in part to the Obama EPA's illegal war on coal. They are very much like Drain and many other single-industry rural communities in America, most of which don't have easy-to-make-fun-of names. Pruitt's announcement is a good thing for these people. The Register-Guard headline editor seems far more interested in mocking the town's name in the cause of potential future global warming than in helping the people who live there who have real problems right now. By the way, the town and Perry County in which it is located were named after a hero of the War of 1812, Oliver Hazard Perry, who was also famed for his battle flag motto "Don't Give Up the Ship" and the saying from his battle report "We have met the enemy and he is ours..." If the people of Hazard have anything like the courage of their namesake, I recommend not mocking them.

Comment: * Yes it is true that if we ordain women priests, under present theology and rules, they can also be bishops. And since the pope is merely the Bishop of Rome, of course we will one day have a female pope. 

* I don't know what you mean by "proper" in a non-moral sense. Best I can make out, you mean the mores of a given age. Mores are always changing, and thus "proper" in that sense also changes. Modesty is the most obvious example. 

* The Church is now a essentially tri-level monarchy -- pope and bishop and pastor are monarchs of their domains -- but the Church has always had and still has democratic elements (councils, and consistories that elect popes, and synods are current democracies; formerly bishops were democratically elected by their clergy or dioceses). There is no reason why the Church could not transform itself into a tri-level democracy. 

* Above all it is our theological morality that has evolved over time. That fact of history is not the same as saying anything goes.

Amend daddy's famous "Charter" to include a section on "Responsibilities" which would include the responsibility not to fight or fundraise in any foreign conflicts except as a legitimate member of the Canadian Forces or Services. "Rights" would be forfeited if these responsibilities are not adhered to."

Ain't gonna happen. The only legal responsibility a citizen has is to obey the law. Everything else is permissible. 

There are actions that are considered one's civic or moral duty such as voting and charitable acts. But you can't mandate them. Comment: Finally, your charge that the HI ll fleet is a "small but powerful" lobby that we need to somehow protect the oceans against is one of the more laughable elements here.  The HI ll fishery is tiny by most standards.  And where did this whole initiative to expand come from?  PEW is the behemoth here, easily overpowering the longline fleet and its supporters in this whole debacle to the point where no one wants to do a proper assessment of the cost/benefit.  Why doesn't PEW lobby to turn the Bering Sea into a monument?  Talk about bio-diversity, whales, and cultural history right?  In a black and white world placing 30% of the ocean off-limits to everyone but snorkelers would work.  But it's way more complicated than that  and if we rush to do it anyways there will be devastating unintended consequences, which I should note, many environmental groups don't seem to be particularly concerned about.  I wish there were a forum where I could publicly debate you on these and other points.  NPR?

Comment: This is potentially bad news for Canada. If Trump and his cabinet decide to migrate social policy away from federally run transfer payments, then taxes go down. If taxes go down, presumably competitiveness goes up (at the expense of social benefit recipients, of course), and if competitiveness goes up, then that pressures our programs.  I think at this point, the best thing we can do is continue to pursue opportunities on the EurAsian continent and continue reducing the amount of trade we do with the US.

The other thing I think Trump needs to address is wages, as they exist today, not only in the US, but, by extension, Canada and every other trading partner. The fact is that even though productivity has increased 100% in the last 30 years, wages have decreased by 10% and benefits by a lot more, in some cases, benefits have been totally smashed. I think he and his billionaire friends need to make a sincere effort to rectify this situation by producing the money. Don't hold your breath.

Comment: Ms. Zachau-kirk,
Most of Ebey's Reserve is privately owned - a fact many folks don't understand.  Washington State owns acreage in the Reserve, including Fort Ebey, Fort Casey, and Ebey's Landing State Parks. The Federal Government owns around 500 acres within Ebey's Reserve - around 2% of the total  Reserve. But the outlying field and the buildings around the field are not within the Reserve.  The field lies just east of the boundary.  
The Reserve and the Navy sometimes have conflicting missions.  Most would argue that operational expansion at the OLF as proposed in the draft EIS is one of those times.  That is why all of the Reserve partners, and many local concerned citizens, exercised their responsibility to submit comments to the EIS expressing their individual concerns about the proposed increase.  At this point we all hope the folks back in Virginia make the right decisions with the final document, based on the information they have spent so much time and energy to gather.

Comment: I am perfectly okay with lots of Vancouver residents having ancestral roots in China. That is not where the problem sits.

The problem at hand in Vancouver is that Canadian policies have encouraged way too many ultra-rich people with overseas money to buy houses in Vancouver. That is a problem because it prices out local families working at local wages.

Canada could have avoided this problem simply by, over the past 30 years, accepting folks from China in the same numbers but in proportions that reflected the wealth of Canadians (a certain percent middle class, a certain percent upper middle class, a certain percent under middle class, etc). If that had been done, house prices in the Vancouver region would NEVER have shot up to dozens of times the average annual local income.

Comment: The sad reality of baseball is that the Rockies cannot afford to keep Arenado. It was my opinion before this season that the Rockies had a two to three year window to win before they start to bleed young talent. That is still true. If they don't get off to a fast start next season they should trade Arenado while a team acquiring him would still have him under their control for nearly two seasons. Clean out the farm system of a team like the Yankees, Dodgers or Red Sox. I stated repeatedly last winter that the Rocks should trade Cargo while they could, both to free up the $20 million he is getting paid and to acquire young talent. There are two ways to win in baseball the way it is structured these days - you spend obscene money or you constantly stockpile your farm system. In the latter system you have to make tough decisions that mean trading bright young stars. Hopefully you swap a current All-Star for three future stars.

Comment: I love the way Sean uses his own research paper to backup his own argument that the green belt is the cause of insufficient housing supply.

To get the transit systems we need, protect our drinking water and environment and avoid living 50+ miles from the office we need to increase the city's density and improve our urban parklands to make them more attractive.

If you visit London, Paris and NY they have large urban parks, interesting architecture lots of things to do for families.

Comment: "First, determine how much we need to spend on defense. (At 15 percent of the budget, it's too little now, in my view.)"

Here's a more rational alternative:
Cut defense spending to 10%.  
Remove the wage base limit for social security so that the billionaires pay into it
Increase the medicare tax to 2% regardless of income.
Both medicare and SS taxes paid on capital gains as well as income
Get rid of Obamacare, Medicaid, Indian Health Service, VA health system, TriCare...  Go with Medicare for all and cut the bureaucracy.
Eliminate health insurance companies - they add no value to healthcare.
Raise the capital gains tax from 15% to 22.5% - hardly any of the working class of this country gets cap gains.

Comment: East of Eden: The problem is with the loophole in the current law, which apparently applies when people try to enter Canada in places that aren't legal border crossings. The U.S. probably won't take back any of these unauthorized migrants (I think it a misleading to call them refugees as they haven't demonstrably met the criteria for such) as under the current agreement it has no obligation to do so. I'm surprised that nobody on Canada's part thought about this loophole when negotiating the agreement with the Americans. It's not as though it couldn't have been anticipated. The only feasible approach now might be to change our laws to deny permanent status to anybody who illegally enters Canada after being denied refugee status or abandoning a refugee claim in a safe third country. I'm sure the Americans will provide us any information they have about these migrants. For the sake of the integrity of our border, we have to disincentivize illegal entry.

It is a loop hole that must be closed to level the playing field. 

Corporate taxes are already low to encourage business and hiring and investment (in the corp) not as a way to cheat the tax man.   Let's never forget in the eyes of the law a corporation is a legal person.

Comment: This is traditional Canadian culture.

Back in the 1960s and 1970s, you had young families with kids, the parents working at local jobs in the the area. Maybe it was Langley, or Richmond, or Vancouver.

Anyways, back then, it was the cultural norm. Parents with local jobs would one day say, "hey, let's buy a house", and they would tell a real estate agent to grab a house they had never looked at, and they would plunk down a suitcase, maybe containing a million dollars, maybe containing four million dollars, and voila, the house was theirs!

And often they would not move into it right away. Maybe not in the first 90 days. Maybe not in the first two years. The young family with local jobs would just sort of hold on to it, like a keepsake, sitting empty.

In the 1960s an 1970s, hundreds of thousands of young families did that all around Vancouver, working at local jobs there.

So Justin Trudeau and other government players are doing well at preserving Canadian tradition.

OK, sarcasm off.

Comment: "Greens with a mere 16% of the popular vote, now wield a power vastly out of proportion to their percentage of votes."

The Greens are wielding that power in our CURRENT system. 

I note you are conveniently omitting the fact that the Greens got 16.5% of the votes and yet they're getting only 3.5% of the seats. Though they might hold the balance of power, they're still short-changed for representation.

This not a partisan issue.

Federal conservative party in 1993 got ~16% of the votes and wound up with ~1% of the seats. 

The status quo might favor a party I support, but I can't defend that outcome.

And cut the fear mongering: there are plenty of examples of functional democracies that have proportional systems. 

At the provincial and federal level, we very typically have "majority" governance that is secured with <40% of votes. 

The "stability" the present system offers ONLY exists because the system often lets elected officials ignore the voting will of the majority of voters.

Comment: Toronto Toronto Toronto - all focus is on how to accommodate Toronto's growth - increase supply, lower costs keep speculators out. But here's the thing: the 5 year growth of Ontario is 600,000.  - 4.7%. Of this, the growth in the GTA was 400,000, or a growth rate of 6.2%; the growth of the rest of the province was 200,000, or a growth rate of 2.4%. Conclusion - by far most of Ontario's growth is channeled into the GTA. In fact, if the Ottawa and Kitchener-Waterloo areas are taken out of the equation, Ontario's population probably shrank.
Which suggests as part of long term planning, the provincial and federal governments should offer encouragements to growth in other parts of Ontario beyond the GTA.

Comment: There are lots of factors that contribute to the hotter fires.  There has always been some fire suppression but when there are houses that suppression is increased so more fuel can accumulate to make hotter fires.  It is also getting hotter and drier which adds to the problem.
My grandfather built a little cabin in one of these transition zones about 0ne hundred years ago.  When people started living there year round the ecology changed rapidly.  Part of the reason people started living there year round was because there was not a much snow in the winter so they could.
Ventilation is a key when the wind blows a thousand degree fire along with windows and siding. It would be best not to build in these areas because to the ecology but if it is allowed code should look at more than little fires.

Comment: It is not a question of whether the county can tax enough to give employees what they want.  Of course they can.  The question is what is reasonable pay.  This cannot be answered by referencing pay to other counties as all counties face zero competition or need to be frugal. This one Lane county voter suggests that the county lock the doors for at least one month once the unions strike.  Think of the possible park improvements enabled.

Comment: I've represented a few Native children in child custody cases and they have to be enrolled in a tribe in order to be recognize mainstream court's child in need of assistance (CINA) cases. A good tribal lawyer can wrap this mess up and bring the children back to their tribe and family.

Comment: When I was on vacation there a week ago I stopped to talk to who I call "poor lonely railroad dude". He was one of the poor guys that have to stand there 24/7 because the signal rail system keeps going nuts. He's out there all night at about Tennyson and W. 58th Ave. and its sparsely populated there. All he had for company was his diesel generator and floodlights.

I said it seemed like he might be bored and he said "Mostly but it does get exciting as that evening two people had already run or crashed into the signal arms." Nice guy.

Anyway his remarks about the signaling system was one of disbelief. Said suddenly one moment all over town signal arms will start going up and down and they can't figure out what is wrong. I mentioned I was a retired mechanical engineer and he said, "Come to work for us and help us solve this nutty crossing problem !" Of course I am happily retired and said as much. This is taking a long time and lots of $$$. Might be best to just bridge the old wiring.

Comment: You are missing something.  In the morning when West Oahu commuters are leaving to go to work/school(actually besides students, many workers work at a school) in the Manoa/Makiki/Waikiki areas & they are all trying to catch the train at the same time, the Hoopili rail station will be a major bottleneck.  You can only load one train at a time and having a couple thousand people all trying to board simultaneously can easily cause an additional 1/2 hour or longer delay at the Hoopili station.   Also, unlike City buses on the road that can travel one behind the other, for safety the trains must be spaced apart probably at least mile which is the distance from one Oahu train stop to the next.  If there is a delay of one train at a stop, that will delay ALL trains behind the stopped train.  The train might have mechanical or electrical problems or if you have seen YouTube train suicides, if someone commits suicide on the Oahu train,  HPD will shut down the entire Oahu rail for many HOURS.

Comment: You call it a 'fact' but it's a fringe definition accepted by some but not by all... that's not a 'fact'. The mainstream definition (found in dictionaries etc) is still the 'old' definition of 'racism' as antipathy towards a group or individual on the basis of race. You can't say someone who disagrees with you is 'simply wrong' because they don't subscribe to the same orthodoxies. 

This is a problem with the Echo Chambers of the web. I'm familiar with spaces wherein the 'new definition' holds (like 'Salon', 'Daily Vox' and so on) but also with those where the 'old definition' holds (like 'The Atlantic', CNN and so on)... but I think your degree of confidence over the 'correct' definition of a hotly contested word is misguided as the issue is not as simple as you seem to think.

The useful work-around here is to avoid the term 'racism' entirely and use 'bigotry' or 'chauvinism' instead. No-one's tried to muddy those waters yet.

Comment: Looking at the original study and maps I can't help but wonder how much of the problem of income mobility is tied to the persistent poverty among a large portion of our native population.

We know, from various other studies and statistics, that indigenous people, particularly those living on reserves, tend to have much higher rates of poverty than non-indigenous people in Canada, and they have for many generations.  If you have a region with a lot of indigenous people living in poverty from generation to generation then income mobility is going to be reduced in that area.

If that really is one factor behind this than any solution would need to be targeted rather than a more general attempt to "fix" the problem at a national level.

Comment: Times change and they always have. Though testing appears to be overemphasized there was a reason for it being so in the first place (i.e. the educational product being turned out was cause for alarm). We can blame the test, we can blame the curriculum, and we can blame the teachers; however; the education is out there to be had. The students who really want it and go after it do well. There are a great number of parents who see nothing wrong with the quality of education and they have raised the students to prove it. Too many excuses are afforded for failure. Teachers are not being turned out in the volume to meet the demands for a blame oriented structure called our educational system. Students are behind and are not at grade level and there are schools of thought that de-emphasize homework. Really, how badly do we want an education?

Comment: "What now"  "Harvard Review" cont....

By the admission of Grandjean and Choi, these studies had key information missing, inadequate control for confounders, and questionable methodologies.  These 27 studies  were so  flawed that they  issued a  2012 statement that the studies should not judge water fluoridation in the US.  

 "These results do not allow us to make any judgment regarding possible levels of risk at levels of exposure typical for water fluoridation in the U.S. 

----Anna Choi, research scientist in the Department of Environmental Health at HSPH, lead author, and Philippe Grandjean, adjunct professor of environmental health at HSPH, senior author.

There is no "2014 Lancet Review shows that fluoride is one of 11 chemicals that damage a developing brain."

There is no valid, peer-reviewed scientific evidence of any "potential of brain damage" from optimally fluoridated water.  Yes, benefit far outweighs unsubstantiated claims of antifluoridationists.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: The argument that the fluoridation of our water supply is the best (and only) effective solution to the "problem" of tooth decay, especially child tooth decay, is a hollow argument. It has no basis in either fact or logic. 

Tooth decay is not caused by our pristine water supply so why "poison" Hawai'i's pure, clean water with such a controversial chemical additive ?

We do know that one of the major causes of tooth decay is the high sugar content in the processed food that makes up the great bulk of the disastrously unhealthy American and western diet.

Hawaiians had little incidence of tooth decay because our diet consisted of fresh-caught fish and naturally, organically grown food. 

The solution to the problem of tooth decay is simple. Ban the American diet including ALL processed foods and replace it with a healthy, natural, organically grown diet of REAL food.

The switch to REAL food will virtually eliminate tooth decay with the added benefit of vibrant health for the everyone.

Comment: The best way to go see Mt. McKinley/Denali in my opinion respectfully EIDOLON, is to take the train from Anchorage to the Park. It is one of the most beautiful train rides in all of North America. I've yet to see one that compares in the lower 48. It allows some of the most beautiful scenic views and abundance of wildlife, an unforgettable showcase of Alaska's great wealth of nature.
As A kid, the Alcan Highway through Canada used to be 1400 miles unpaved, which every time a truck blew by left one in a mile of dust to eat, today most is paved! It was hard on cars! LOL!~ But that highway as it goes through the Yukon Territory also offers some spectacular views.
Driving the Seward Highway out Anchorage is one very relaxing drive as it winds it's way. 
They tore it down, but for years, the old town of Valdez that was washed in the '64 tidal wave from the earthquake was a fun place see. Used to play as a kid in the shell of a DC3, and old abandon 30's cars as kids that were left in place!

For example it isn't so much as the environment and even the grooming that a players gets, at any organization, but the context and the will to succeed with the ingrained talent he has.  We've heard the nonsesne:"well just send him to the AHL." Like  boot camp fixes everything; which is the notion, Leafs and their fans have held for years.   The real context is that the game has always shifts,: the talent if identified properly, always floats to the top, if the will to play becomes a defining aspect of the player. Comment: Here's my strategy:
1) My wife and I take CPP at 60 - we retired in our 50s.
2) Invest the money - max out our TFSAs, with the rest in a standard investment account.
- using this strategy, based on a 6% return, I calculate a net worth benefit until well into our mid-80's.
- after that, net worth is negatively impacted, but not dramatically
3) Use the TFSAs as supplemental medical and long term care funds, if needed
- do not buy supplemental medical insurance or long term care insurance - a further net worth improvement, if the funds are not required
4) With the first death, the surviving spouse's CPP will revert to the max, restoring the CPP reduction caused by taking it early
- a little life insurance for the surviving spouse

Comment: There is no path forward if the US wants Chapter 19 scrapped.  The US antidumping law is a 1930's relic that imposes penalties as soon as a complaint is filed, but lifts them only when the accused party proves they are not dumping.  Virtually any company with enough legal resources can file such a complaint.  This is why NAFTA, WTO, and - until the US choked - the TPP used other dispute resolution mechanisms.  If the US won't drop this it is  better to fall back to WTO rules and negotiate a new NAFTA agreement after Trump is gone than tolerate constant trade meddling through US courts.

Anything big enough to move the needle in Omaha is also big enough to be visible to millions of investors who've read all the Buffettologies out there. If Warren and Charlie one day decide to follow the examples of Apple, Microsoft and Cisco and start letting a little air out of the tire by paying a dividend, you won't hear me complaining.

Comment: yes, taxation. I argue against the defunct "neo-liberal" idea that the basic requirements of human civilisation are best performed by unregulated corporations who exist for private shareholder value in the short term. That is free market ideology. I regard what used to be called a "mixed economy" as a better principle - government sets policy objectives through democratic political processes where money does not do all the talking, and regulates private markets accordingly, thereby reducing harmful externalities, and pursuing positive, sensible, societal ends.  I do not see the relevance of Venezuela, which is not even a democracy. On cars, the mixed economy is working wonders (USA - which is a mixed economy despite the myth, and Japan, Germany and others), as auto makers move to electric cars, in indicative policy environments and regulation to render the internal combustion engine at long last obsolete, along with the fossil fuel industry basis for mass transportation.

Comment: The Examiner will go to any length to justify its conservative ideology. In fact, the move to independence and the establishment of a government based on a constitution was a radical move--not as radical as the French Revolution--but radical nevertheless. And in the political alignments of its time, a liberal move, not conservative. Further, most of the major changes that flowed from that initial liberal revolution are liberal themselves, with conservatives usually in opposition. The end of slavery, the establishment of a national bank, and the eventual financial system that made the industrial revolution in this country possible, the concept of a social safety net, the union movement, our entry into world politics, the civil rights movement, the environmental movement, the emancipation of the LGBT community were and are liberal in their orientation. Conservatives have a very difficult time coming with an equivalent list of accomplishments.

Comment: That's not totally true.  It's true every other developed country has a universal health care system but the set up can be multi-payer such as in Germany, Netherlands, and Switzerland.  The difference is in those countries insurance is compulsory, its illegal to refuse someone, and rates are set based on income not health.  In many ways Obamacare was modeled similar to the Dutch system whereas ours is modeled off the British system.  We use the Beveridge system which is funded through general taxation whereas Germany uses the Bismarckian system which is funded through social insurance.  Also many European countries have user fees, co-payments, or reliance on private health insurance in areas we don't and would be political suicide to propose.  Essentially for primary care we are one of the most socialistic, US most capitalistic and Europe generally falling in between the two.

Comment: CPI is not intended to reflect the day to day or even month to month price changes in your local store.  But rather the longer term average price change of what is actually a pretty complex basket of goods (measuring about 600 goods and services within 175 classes).

That 5% price change in your local store averaged out over a longer period of time most certainly is closer to what the CPI is measuring.

Comment: "All models are wrong, but sometimes they're helpful." To achieve these savings, this model assumes Canada's governments can immediately lower the cost of this limited list of drugs to the level of a selected group of comparators in different systems with different governance and that have taken years to attain what they have. This is interesting, but unrealistic. Canada's per capita drug cost is the third highest in the world after the US and Japan. I think we'd want to see government management achieve much more before we give them this massive and crucial responsibility. 

While I know we need universal drug insurance, this list is only a beginning. It won't solve access to high-cost specialty drugs that routinely cost tens of thousands of dollars a year. It can't answer for decades of government indifference. And it ignores the social insurance model that is very successful in Europe. But at least it keeps the discussion going, and maybe some day governments will respond.

Comment: As I have observed, there must be limits. The risk of chaos should be the guideline as to the imposition of limits; in the case of abortion, that risk is small, but the impacts of the decision are great. We, as a nation, have honored the right of individuals to make this type of decision, even when we shudder at the result; this is consistent with my observations on free will decision making and our relationship with God. I think that we need to halt the damage that is being done by the Pro-Life faction in putting their focus on elimination choice; that has always led to practices going underground, not extinguishing practices. It would be far better to establish social constructs that encourage the choice to carry to term, and simultaneously mount a long-term campaign (not unlike the anti-smoking campaign in the US) that seeks to move public opinion to a position where abortion is not a preferred alternative. This is hard work, but it preserves autonomy while moving to a desired goal.

Comment: An actual change to a "popular" vote for the Presidency would be an interesting proposal and, as you suggest, change the entire landscape of the Presidential campaigns.  It would, in fact, make states with small populations, if anything, even less significant.  Campaigns would be won or lost in the "popular vote" battleground states...California, New York, Florida...etc. Oregon would be a "so what" state. 

On the other hand, I'd like to see a change to a "ranked/preferential" system which would alllow third party and independent candidates to compete w/o the burden of a "wasted vote" impacting the election.  Our current two party domination of our political system is, IMO, the real issue.  
Gary Crum

Comment: I think you need to dig deeper with your analysis. Prior to Castro most Cubans who worked on farms worked for large agribusinesses owned primarily by Americans. Comment: Mis-managed? By whom? Did that same entity cause Hurricane Harvey? The above average temps for the past decades? 
The fact is that all forests always have burned; it's an historical fact and actually necessary for healthy forests--- it kills tree diseases, eliminates sick trees, renews the forest floor. 
But, corporate forest management for over 100 years here in the NW has practiced clear-cutting and that overcrowds the land with fast-growing trees that are far smaller: perfect for canopy fires!
The solutions would be more diverse-and-spaced planting, the clearing of underbrush and smaller trees, and prescribed burns. The forest service also needs to stop fighting all fires: ground fires and some potential canopy ones can be allowed to burn assuming contain fires can be utilized.

Furthermore, the plenary power doctrine has its roots not in the constitution, but in racist immigration laws of the 1800's.  That's why courts have limited the effect of the doctrine.  
Instead, the travel should be evaluated based on its ability to reduce terrorism in the U.S., as Trump says it will.  However, the addition of North Korea to the travel ban shows that the purpose of the travel ban is not to reduce terrorism.  North Korea is a closed country, and almost no North Koreans visit the U.S.  Those few are largely diplomats going to the U.N., and they are allowed under the travel ban.  There have been no terrorist incidents in the U.S. caused by North Korean immigrants.  
Apparently, Trump added North Korea to the travel ban to make it appear that it wasn't a Muslim ban.  It's still racist.

Comment: User Awareness is the key. I am embarrassed  to admit this, but the other day I got scammed by an outfit in India. My computer completely froze and a message with a voice- over popped up telling me to call a number for Microsoft support as my computer had a lethal virus. I called the number----BIG MISTAKE!!! ---I was on the phone for 20 minutes with a very nice Indian lady who guided me through a process that unbeknownst to me allowed her access to all the info on my computer. Fortunately I did not pay for the security package that she was selling at the end--as many others have done. The scam is known as FASTSUPPORT.  I had to cancel all bankcards, get my computer cleaned and change all passwords---big pain. If this ever happens to anyone out there take my hard earned advice: turn off your computer immediately, take the battery out and above all DO NOT CALL any numbers that pop-up on your screen. Hope this helps others who might fall prey to these crooks.

Comment: John Rlecke wrote:  "Everyone wants a train but no one has any idea how a train actually works. Hint: one thing is you need people and places to go, not empty asphalt, fields, or a dozen single family homes."

John, you nailed that.  I'm from Chicago.  When riding the 'L' you can watch people doing their laundry, watching TV, eating dinner while you pass by.  We lived 8.6 miles from Union Station on a commuter line.  12 minutes downtown on an express train.  It's funny, except it's not, when I have to stop for a light rail train (light rail has half the calories of regular rail), it reminds me of a toy train set.

I'll also note that 10% of Chicagoland jobs are downtown.  Here in Denver it's only 2%.  I live in the city and commute to the 'burbs.  Transit in no way serves me well.  I'm not anti-transit, but I sure didn't vote for this boondoggle in 2004.

Omaha did it right:  http://www.ometro.com/index.php/rideorbt/

And Bogotá:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TransMilenio

Comment: Shenfield is quoted as saying ““June’s job gains were widely spread across goods and services, split evenly between paid jobs and self-employment, with the only disappointment being a leaning to part-time jobs.” Seriously? So if there was a relatively strong 0.25% increase in all jobs, there was a substantially weaker 0.15% growth in employee jobs. Self-employed jobs grew by 0.77% but these are mostly lower-paid and part-time jobs, and thence part of the lean to part-time jobs if you do a full-time part-time split. This is also part of the explanation for their being no increase in nominal average hourly earnings at all in June; so even though the job numbers were good, real wage growth continues to disappoint.

Comment: Where to even start. Your comment assumes some deference to the two-party framework, and yet a majority of us Coloradans are registered as unaffiliated and aren't particularly swayed by partisan dismissals and hand-waving. That said, my recollection of the development and passage of the Affordable Care Act back in the day was that it was mostly good, excepting that it was subverted to support for-profit medicine instead of single-payer by the Republicans. It was a huge bill, but its development was not a trade secret. You may be remembering some personal TL;DR type reaction, but something being "too long, too hard" is hardly the same thing as a secret conspiracy. There's no apology sufficient for opaqueness in the process of domestic and civil legislation, and it would appear the far-right authoritarians don't recognize the public limits of their own competence and credibility. We demand an open process, credible objective outside experts: all aimed at non-profit social progress.

Re: "moving the reserve".  In pre-industrial west coast, that's exactly what the coastal peoples once did.  A village would occupy a site for a number of years and then--for health and sanitary reasons, usually--they'd leave it (and their long houses, too!) and move elsewhere and build again.

Comment: As a non-economist, I can accept the doctrine of comparative advantage as a starting point for formulating a national trade policy.  However, it is not the only criterion a nation might use.  For example, we might want to ensure we can produce our own weapons for self defense or acquire them reliably from a friendly ally.  We might want to ensure that the origin of comparative advantage in our trading partner is not created by the use of child or slave labour.  We might want to ensure that what we import as food is healthy and free from contaminants. We might want to ensure that the origin of comparative advantage does not result from global environmental contamination that will ultimately be harmful locally.  We might want to attempt to develop a comparative advantage by encouraging innovation and new methods of production even though in the short run we may be higher cost producers.  In short, there are many reasons why a nation may choose not to be a slave to comparative advantage.

Comment: The other thing is - I question your understanding of practicality when it comes to tradesmen.

When you have several thousand dollars worth of portable tools, you have a three options with a pickup. Get a lockable cap for your bed, get locking storage boxes which you bolt to the bed (and there goes your ability to carry a sheet of plywood flat), OR you use the back seat of your extended cab as a locker. 

THAT is why vehicles like a Ford Transit or a Sprinter are becoming more popular. They are far more practical (especially for Canada where we have a thing called "winter"). They can keep tools secure AND have room for materials AND have a full length roof rack system for items like pipe, ladders, etc.

It's also a free market and it's not profitable for companies to spend millions providing services to small and spread-out communities that want these same services for free or at least subsidized. People in urban areas get the service because it makes business sense, and there is a population to justify the effort to provide the service with a mass market price tag. Alaskans living in remote areas have not paid for their own airports, medical facilities, etc. or anything else of that nature -- the state and feds and have always covered the cost. Comment: Before globalization, advances in technology and other disrupting factors corporate concentration was greater than it is now yet the wealth gap was not growing; workers could look forward to a modest but steady growth living standards and did not fear for their children's future,

With the advent of global supply chains this model was broken; companies now have to maximize profit to satisfy investors and to provide products and services at the lowest possible price for consumers in order to remain competitive.  This led to the growth in lobbying funded by corporations and the wealthy to influence legislation favourable to their goals.

Government has the responsibility ensure that corporations act for the common good and should strive to do so through sensible regulation that encourages distribution of wealth more equitably and ensures that ethical standards are maintained.  Most governments are failing to do so to the detriment of democracy.

Comment: The economic relationship that has developed within NAFTA has been one of mutual advantage. It has evolved as a free competitive market and bears all the hallmarks of efficiency that Adam Smith would expect. Nobody has been coerced, so deals have been made only when both parties benefit.

Often in economics we discuss efficiency, and as a counterpoint we bring up the notion of equity, or fairness. Efficiency and fairness are two separate outcomes, and you rarely get one without sacrificing the other.

If Trump wants fairness (whatever that means!), he's going to have to sacrifice efficiency, which will reduce the wealth and well-being of all the NAFTA trading partners. Trump (among others) needs to understand more of economics. When the government interferes in markets and distorts prices, there are very seldom good outcomes, and never efficient ones . Also, what makes sense in profit oriented business in the micro scale tends to have disastrous consequences in the macro economy.

Comment: You can Google and find a visual that shows how much of the land mass is owned/controlled by Federal or State government.  Land/water/species conservation is one thing.  Much of the other "environmental stuff" is a whole different ballgame and costly both environmentally and fiscally. Plastic bags, glass, and paper recycling make no sense to me.  The supermarket can't give me a plastic bag to bring home for my wastebasket, storing Christmas decorations, collecting small items in a bunch, or collecting the kitchen garbage. I save every single plastic bag I can, including those containing my newspaper.  Then I buy plastic bags for many other uses.  All of this collecting is supposed to make us feel righteous, I guess.   As for glass, there's no shortage of sand on the planet, and I use jars for myriad purposes.  It's not the items that are bad; it's what irresponsible people do with them.   Here's an article of interest:  https://www.disabled-world.com/artman/publish/recycling.shtml

Comment: Before the MarineMammal Protecton Act, I consumed polar bear meat on numerous occasions. It was usually boiled, then dipped in seal oil (from oogruks -the best). While assisting other guides on hunts, I always brought in at least the hams & gave a lot away to friends & neighbors in Kotzebue. One evening, at a gathering of hunters & peripheral folks, an inebriated taxidermist from Spokane berated me for bringing in meat.  The slurry-speached fellow suggested I enjoy some liver, & bet me $500 that I would not. So I said, "Its a bet, then"  He said I should show up with cash as I would be dead before he could cash a check. We shook hands, with witnesses.
So the next evening he showed up with a large lobe of pb liver. We each showed our cash. I fried up a sliver of liver, & ate it. He protested, I bet on eating pb liver -not a WHOLE liver. After 2 hours of drinking & grousing, he handed over the $500. I suffered not at all, bought a new SnoJet for $600, laughed my way home.

Its true we have unused generation capacity today, we didn't before the 2008/2009 recession. Since then we recouped a great deal of capacity from the closing of industries. That capacity is also spread across the entire Provinces generation system and not readily or easily routed to where demand is needed. Which is why many areas of the Province get their power from the U.S., Manitoba and Quebec, and vice versa. What happens if EVs are charging overnight in the U.S., Manitoba and Quebec? The grid that interconnects us is going to radically change if that time comes..... continued

Comment: Not at all.  In "Perfectae Caritatis" - the Vatican II document on the renewal of religious life - religious orders of both men and women were asked to rediscover the roots of their founders and the specific charisms of their communities.  Many discovered that their order was (a) never intended to wear habits, or (b) forced by bishops into wearing them against the protestations of the founding members, (c) were actually the same sort of dress worn by the populace of the time, added to over the years for various but inconsequential reasons, or (d) particularly for women religious, needed relief from the torture of wearing clothing that cut or irritated the skin, causes heat stroke in the summer and was of little defense against freezing temperatures.  There are almost no orders that have maintained a full traditional habit....most have modified at least the most extreme aspects.  Unless, of course, you appear on EWTN.  Then, even monks run to find an old habit of theirs to wear.

Comment: The re-imposition of specific sanctions against Iran's military for its ballistic missile program made this move problematic since the Revolutionary Guards control an estimated 78% of Iran's economy through a myriad of shell companies, including the Ministry of Telecommunications governing all phones and internet access. The IRGC uses the profits to fund its proxy wars in Yemen and Syria, as well as supply cash to terrorist groups such as Hezbollah. It's important to remember that the vast majority of the Iranian economy is state-controlled so this move was unavoidable. Hopefully it begins the process of applying the kind of pressure that led to the nuclear negotiations in the first place, but this time we shouldn't appease the regime and this time tie improvements in human rights, women's rights and freedom of the press to a new deal. Ultimately that would be a greater service to the Iranian people.

Comment: Actually, St. Nicholas day isn't really our Santa Claus,  St. Nicholas day is celebrated on 6 December for Western Christians and 19 December for Eastern Christians (My family puts up our tree up on 6 December to celebrate this day/St. Nicholas.).  "Our" Santa Claus is really a mash-up of "traditions surrounding the historical Saint Nicholas, a fourth-century Greek bishop and gift-giver of Myra, the British figure of Father Christmas, the Dutch figure of Sinterklaas (himself based on Saint Nicholas), the German figure of the Christkind (a fabulized Christ Child [Kris Kringle]), and the holidays of Twelfth Night and Epiphany and their associated figures of the Three Kings (based on the gift-giving Magi of the Nativity) and Befana."

Additionally, some folklorists theorize that all versions of Santa Claus begin with the Germanic pagan god, Wodan and German Christianization.

Full disclosure, I am an agnostic Christian who believes in the teachings of Jesus the Jew.  Merry Christmas"

Thirty-five years ago, in a case known as Seneca College v. Bhadauria, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled that one can't sue in court based on a breach of the Human Rights Code.  Since then, the appropriate forum (for a non-union employee) is to use Human Rights Tribunals.

To the best of my knowledge, class action law suits based solely on Human Rights violations don't escape this ruling.

The Ontario Human Rights Code allows a limited right to sue, depending on whether there are other non-civil rights claims in the suit.  I'm not aware that the Canadian Human Rights Act has a similar provision.

Comment: With great respect to all Coupeville and Central Whidbey residents, I think it's "unpatriotic" to move into a naval training area and then demand that the entire nation subsidize your choice by paying for a new outlying field or endanger our troops' safety for your choice.

Comment: There are too many variables to try to predict an outcome on the basis of anything so simple as "up or out." In fact, designers and planners have made horrific choices for cities because they believe that they can predict a historical outcome on the basis of the few variables that seem, at the moment, the most important. In ten years, it turns out that they were not the most important variables after all. And there are of course values in tension in these disputes--and the values are all important in different ways to different people, and the hierarchies of these values change as conditions change. It's not a matter of simple right and wrong.

I'm far less interested in a "solution" than I am in a process that involves all the people that will be in some way impacted, a process that happens slowly over time so that there are opportunities for changes and adjustments and even retreats, and a process that checks on actual outcomes along the way--and I mean checks in a democratic way.

Comment: You state your argument well, ... and, unfortunately, that's the biggest challenge with nuclear weapons on top of missiles.
When Japan dealt a devastating blow to Pearl Harbor, we still had the opportunity for the entire country to be made aware of it, for Congress to convene, for the president to state his case, and for Congress to deliberate and vote.
When Saudi terrorists attacked us on 9/11, the investigators could use the time to determine the attack came from the Taliban, George Bush, jr could issue an ultimatum to Afghanistan, and then the president could propose a response to Congress. People at the time, and now, can question why the Saudis were given a free pass. or question whether the ultimatum was appropriate, or question whether The Patriot Act was the right thing. But that's just it: There was time to respond. Time to argue. Time for Congress to debate.
In a large nuclear attack with missiles, there is no time for deliberation. Only time to react.

Comment: My current neighborhood is North Capitol Hill, but I'll move back down into Capitol Hill, proper, by Thanksgiving.

When we first moved to Denver, in 1975, we lived in West Highland. It was pretty rough, as busing had started to move Hispanics into the local schools.

The blue collar families who lived there, at the time, deeply resented the Hispanic presence, and the children parroted the talk and the attitudes they heard from their parents. There were lots of fights, back then.

Comment: [We have one of the last centrist politicians on the red side.]
As a centrist I wouldn't call Murkowski a centrist.  Firstly, centrism isn't "middle of the road," "fence-sitting," etc. but a ideology that we as a nation and as a result of our governing system got to where we are with good reason.  This generally means resisting any big shifts one way or the other.
Secondly, Murkowski is consistently conservative in about 90% of her stances.  There are two areas she consistently breaks from her party though.  Namely reproductive rights and hate crimes.  But for gun rights, gay marriage, pro-development, etc. etc. etc. even affirmative women's rights Murkowski votes alongside most Republicans.
I don't think Murkowski's issue on the Republican healthcare bill is shifting the healthcare issue a good distance to the right so much as the disregard for proper process and inclusion of viewpoints.

Comment: JC,

That is not a very good analogy. For one, you don't actually possess the right to have a lawful society, thought you do benefit from one in Canada. Second, a common test placed on ones freedom to act in society without hindrance is the harm principle. Using this test, one can can clearly establish that those who exceed the speed limit are more likely to cause accidents that could physically and demonstrably harm others. Therefore, they are prohibited from doing so by the law. Ones unwillingness to use another individuals desired pronoun or support their chosen way of life does not sufficiently harm the other in a demonstrable fashion. Hurt feelings is not enough to meet the harm principle test or we'd be in a world of problems as everyone would be before the court for hurting others feelings one way or another. One should have the right to their chosen gender identity, no question, but that right need not require others to do anything but not impede their choice.

Comment: I agree that cutting the dividend takes money out of the economy. So does budget cuts and more taxes. So does low oil prices and reduced spending by the oil companies. I also agree that we must spend more from savings than we would like in order to ramp down to a sustainable budget level. If you believe the economic forecast we will need to do all of the above now that the oil boom is over. At this point, the dividend is economic "crack" that has helped to build an economic bubble that is unsustainable into the future. It is ridiculous that we send an estimated 10-15% of the dividend to the feds right off the top. We would be best off to phase it out over then next two years and keep that money in our reserves. If we play our cards right we can keep the negative impact of any future broad based taxes to a minimum.

Comment: I was curious about this so I asked my own mortgage broker, who said: "I think they are missing the point if they pass this. It will not target the wealthy as much as it will target those in high cost areas." As I understand it from a recent DP article - http://www.denverpost.com/2017/11/03/how-many-people-have-half-million-dollar-homes/ - half a million here buys you a bigger-than-average home, but half a million in a place like San Francisco buys you one bedroom, one bath. So, it would seem, the "target" here is not so much "the wealthy," but where you live. And that is the subject of David Brooks' recent op ed titled "The Clash of Social Visions" - you can read it @ https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/opinion/republicans-taxes-cuts.html - The devil, they say, is in the details. Comment: Of course it wouldn't succeed. The Supreme Court has ruled a number of times that monuments are legal, and large monuments are legal. They've also addressed expansions- in a case in the 1970s called US vs California which dealt with the expansion of then- Channel Islands national monument in 1949.  the court ruled that, even though a 3 mile band of water stretching from the coast of CA belonged to the state, the monument expanding into state waters was valid, as the US retained a stake in the waters. Expansions are part of the presidents discretion. this includes how much land and water to add. Most of FDRs uses of the Act were expansions to existing monuments. More recent presidents dont expand existing monuments as much, Obama has only expanded a monument 3 times. So any anti-monument challenge is going to fail, as the states dont have standing to challenge, and monuments are the presidents call, and his alone. Courts aren't going to overturn them.

Comment: If the buildings without sprinklers really are putting their occupants at risk, then units in those buildings are worth less than otherwise comparable buildings with sprinklers.  I suspect that they are not assessed at less.  If that is so, then the city council should take the difference in tax between what owners of units without sprinklers pay, and what they would pay if the difference in value was incorporated in the assessment, and put that money into a special fund that those condo associations can draw on to upgrade the safety of their buildings.  If buildings without sprinklers are in fact assessed at less than comparable buildings with sprinklers, the City Council should gross them up to the assessment they would have if they had sprinklers and put that money in a fund the building associations could draw on.  Either way, the buildings would have a strong incentive to submit plans to install sprinklers or otherwise make the buildings safer to get their money back.

Comment: for a glimpse of the future, consider the new International arrivals terminal at the Calgary International Airport.

previously, international arrivals were asked to pre-fill the standard Customs form, and weave their way to a series of manned kiosks where a human agent reviews the form, and sends you on your way to the final area exit, where an agent reviews the previous agents assessment and send you on your way.

Agents encountered - 2 

Now, an agent greets you in front of a gleaming bank of automatic customs forms readers, telling you, and everyone else, to find an open machine.  That's 1 person.
Then you insert the form, the machine does its thing, and prints out a facsimile. Another agent directs you to a lineup. That's 2 people.

A person at the head of the lineup reads the machine generated form, and then either directs you to the same old lineup of manned kiosks, or to the luggage carousel. That's 3 people.

Then one final review, and you're free. That's 4 people. The future

Comment: Thank you for the clarification regarding what the Mass actually is.  It is often confused with the Last Supper for many reasons, especially what was taught to us in Catholic schools, and the fact that the words of Consecration come directly from the Gospel accounts of the Passover meal of Jesus and His disciples.  Understandable mistake, don't you agree? To further understand the Mass we also, importantly, need the Easter Sunday miracle.  But I must add a note of disagreement with your statement (traditionalist as it is) of:"...the priest is not "representing" Jesus but instead stands in His person, presenting His sacrifice to the Father for the people."  Vatican II was exceptionally clear that there is a second and equally vital part to that equation, and that is that the Presence of Christ occurs through the union of priest and congregation.  I am always surprised when anyone leaves that out of any discussion of the Eucharistic liturgy or its theology.  The laity need not be "led."

Comment: Oh my.  What a spin job.  OF COURSE Social Security is one of the spending items that factors into annual federal deficits/surpluses.  And I'm talking about the REAL deficit/surplus (total revenues minus total outlays), not this silly on-budget/off-budget technicality that some try to hide behind.  What counts is the TOTAL.

And it's not just SS.  Medicare, Medicaid, SCHIP, welfare, food stamps, etc etc all contribute to an overall domestic spending total that's been soaring for decades (at the expense of national defense).  In 1960, defense spending was 10% of GDP, and domestic spending was 8%.  Today defense spending is below 4% of GDP while domestic spending is a whopping 18% of GDP.  And we've run deficits in nearly every year. Anyone that doesn't think this is mostly a domestic spending problem has their head in the ground.

Now, back to FY2009 alone... guess what, we had a recession that year.  We have recessions on average once every 6 years in the US. And they always (cont.)...

Comment: Mentioned regularly that Your Js have the worst BA in the AL with RISP.  What is never mentioned, though, is that Your Js also have the worst BA, period.

In terms of ranking, the correlation between the 2 sets of data is consistent.  Generally speaking, teams that hit well, they also hit well with RISP.  So, if a team is ranked near the top of the AL in BA, it's pretty likely they're also ranked 'bout the same when hitting with RISP.

Yes, it's true that Your Js don't hit well with RISP, for sure.  It's also true they don't hit well when runners are not in scoring position.  They don't hit well in any situation.

And it's not just BA, Your Js are 2nd-worst in the AL for OBP, 3rd-worst for SLG, 2nd-worst for OPS.

And fewest runs scored/game in the AL.  Injuries are routinely brought up by the courtiers to explain their dismal year, as if anybody could possibly have ever imagined that players in the mid-30s or with a history of going on the DL would actually get injured.....

Comment: The little problem is the lack of the few drugs that are able to treat a handful of tropical diseases.  The big problem is that there are many untreatable tropical diseases, many of which are contagious.  If you look at the "Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation" website, you see that they call these "Neglected Tropical Diseases" and that more than a billion people are currently infected by them. I have not spent the time necessary to evaluate the threats and opportunities that these diseases create. I just want to point out that with growing interactions between the Western World and the tropical areas of the world, that this (mass of untreatable diseases)  is the elephant in the room - not the lack of a few drugs.

Yes, if you're going the speed limit let them stack up behind you, but if not- 13 AAC 02.050(b)  "...However, on a two-lane highway outside an urban district where passing is unsafe because of oncoming traffic or other conditions, the driver of a motor vehicle proceeding at less than the maximum authorized speed of traffic and behind whom five or more vehicles are formed in a line shall turn off the roadway at the nearest place designated as a turnout or wherever sufficient area for a safe turnout exists in order to permit following vehicles to pass."
